S. Nicorss bishop of Myra, the capitol of Lycia in Lesser Asia, was born at Patara, a town in the same province, about three miles distant from the capital. He early devoted himself to God in the religious life, aud was appointed abbat of the monastery of the Holy Zion by the bishop of Myra, his predecessor, who had founded it. There he lived in seclusion, l till he was chosen to fill the vacant see of Myra. In this high office he became famous for his great piety and zeal3 which, as ancient writers testify, were honoured by God w‘ith frequent miracles. Instonces of his cherity are recorded, in which he bound those who were indebted to him by a solemn promise not to reveal his name till after his decease.
